plant.description:
Brief Description:
    ◦ Appearance: Plants in the Alocasia genus are generally described as erect perennials that grow from running rhizomes. They typically feature single, long-stemmed, spear-headed leaves with prominent veins. The specific variety Alocasia reginula is known as "Black Velvet."
    ◦ Where Commonly Found: It is a popular indoor houseplant.• Cat toxicity chart for 50 popular houseplants12
• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual

    ◦ Where Commonly Found: It is a popular indoor houseplant.• Cat toxicity chart for 50 popular houseplants12

toxins.name: Insoluble Calcium Oxalate Crystals
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Mechanical Damage: These crystals form needle-like structures known as raphides. When a cat bites or chews into the plant tissue, specialized cells (idioblasts) forcefully eject these microscopic needles into the soft tissues of the mouth, tongue, and throat.
    ◦ Inflammatory Response: This penetration causes immediate and intense physical trauma, leading to severe burning, irritation, and swelling (edema) of the oral cavity and pharynx.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Distribution: These crystals are found in all parts of the plant.
    ◦ Potency: The reaction is immediate and painful, often described as "moderate" severity because the intense pain typically prevents the cat from consuming a lethal amount. However, severe swelling can potentially obstruct the airway.

toxins.name: Proteinaceous Toxins (or proteolytic enzymes)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ The sources indicate that Alocasia species may contain proteinaceous toxins alongside the oxalate crystals. These toxins are released when the plant is damaged and can exacerbate the inflammatory response caused by the crystals, contributing to the intense pain and swelling.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Distribution: Present in leaves, stems, and tubers.
    ◦ Potency: These compounds work synergistically with the calcium oxalate crystals to increase the severity of the irritation.• Cat toxicity chart for 50 popular houseplants1
• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual

symptoms.name: Severe oral irritation; intense burning of the mouth, tongue, and throat
symptoms.notes: The plant contains microscopic crystals that act like needles, causing physical trauma to the mouth tissues.Excessive Drooling (Hypersalivation)

symptoms.name: Drooling
symptoms.notes: This is a physiological response to the acute pain and burning sensation in the oral cavity.Vomiting

symptoms.name: Vomiting
symptoms.notes: Swallowing the plant material or the body's reaction to the intense irritation can trigger vomiting.Difficulty Swallowing (Dysphagia)

symptoms.name: Difficulty swallowing
symptoms.notes: The cat may be unable or unwilling to swallow due to the pain and swelling in the throat.Throat Swelling (Airway Risk)

symptoms.name: Swelling of the throat (Laryngeal edema)
symptoms.notes: While the overall toxicity is often rated as moderate, there is a risk that swelling in the back of the throat could obstruct breathing. Veterinary attention should be sought promptly to monitor for this specific complication.

treatments.name: Oral Decontamination (Rinsing)
treatments.description: The cat's mouth is thoroughly rinsed or wiped out with water to remove any remaining plant material and the microscopic needle-like crystals (raphides) causing the irritation.
treatments.notes: This is the immediate first step to stop the crystals from causing further physical trauma to the soft tissues of the mouth and throat.

treatments.name: Airway Management
treatments.description: The veterinarian monitors for laryngeal edema (swelling of the throat). In severe cases, they may provide oxygen support or secure an airway (intubation) to ensure the cat can breathe.
treatments.notes: While the overall toxicity is often rated as moderate, there is a specific risk that swelling in the back of the throat could obstruct breathing. Immediate intervention is required if the cat shows signs of respiratory distress.

treatments.name: Administration of Calcium-Containing Liquids (Demulcents)
treatments.description: Feeding the cat small amounts of milk, yogurt, or other calcium-containing dairy products.
treatments.notes: The calcium in these products binds to the insoluble oxalate crystals, which helps precipitate them and aids in clearing them from the oral cavity and esophagus, providing soothing relief.

treatments.name: Symptomatic Supportive Care (Analgesics & Fluids)
treatments.description: Administering pain medication (analgesics) to control severe oral discomfort and fluid therapy if the cat is dehydrated from excessive drooling or vomiting.
treatments.notes: Analgesics are indicated because the pain from the crystals is immediate and intense. Most cases recover without extensive intervention, but pain relief helps the cat return to eating and drinking.
